Images of Cutworms

Cutworms are caterpillars that curl tightly into the shape of a 'C' when disturbed. They have plump bodies, smooth skin, and a moist or oily feel. The grayish brown and light brown-speckled variegated cutworm has a single row of pale yellow dots running down either side of its body.
Pinkish Tan

The risk of infestations is highest in crops when dense cover crops or weeds are present at or shortly before crop emergence. They can be observed lying on the ground or partially buried, and cutworms are most noticeable when there are skips or portions of rows when all the plants are missing.
Distribution Area
Common in temperate zones.
Home gardens.

How to identify it?

The adults have 2 pairs of wings and whose wingspan varies from 25 to 45 mm for the species of interest to us. The fore and hind wings present a variable coloring according to the species (reddish brown, brown, gray), as well as more or less characteristic patterns.

The pupa, which measure from 2 to 2.8 cm, has reddish-brown color and can be found at or below soil level. The pupal stage generally lasts 21 to 34 days, but can take longer, depending on the temperature.

The hatch caterpillars measuring 25 to 50 mm depending on the species, equipped with powerful mandibles that allow them to constantly consume plants, especially leave. These caterpillars have a color of green, sometimes becoming brown to reddish as they age, gray-brown with longitudinal black dots, moult several times before pupation or chrysalization.

The eggs color are transparent, white, or black-brown with a diameter less than a millimeter, are deposited singly or in groups on the surfaces of the leaves or various supports. A cutworm will typically lay 350-800 pearl-shaped eggs.

Cutworms are pests that feed on seedlings and chew leaves that touch the ground, and occasionally bore into cabbage heads, usually feeding at night and found during the day just below the soil surface or under dirt clods.

Cutworms damage seedlings and young plants by clipping them off at or just below ground level and they cause severe losses in fields, especially when they are present in large numbers before planting and the damage recurs year after year.
Mow as closely as possible to the edge of your garden to give cutworms less to feed on and less shelter near your plants.
A three-foot wide (or more) bare-soil strip between your lawn and your garden plants makes it harder for larvae to reach your plants.
Plant sunflowers along the edge of your garden.
Cultural Control
Plowing of all fallow land exposes dormant pupae to desiccation and beneficial organisms (predators).
Bund shaving kills pupae.
Young seedlings in seedbeds away from large areas of weeds are less prone to larval attack.
Flooding of nursery beds and stubble prevents larvae migration and reduces survival.
Handpicking of egg masses and larvae from trap crops (Castor) on alternate days following the warning from the pheromone traps reduces their population.
Cutting tops of bundled seedlings before transplanting removes egg masses.
Reducing application of nitrogenous fertilizer lessens their attack.
Clean cultivation exposes pupa to natural enemies and induces weather-related mortality.
Biological Control
Small wasps attack eggs.
Big wasps and tachinid flies kill larvae. Virus infection by NPV is rampant at the larval stage.
Ants feed on eggs and larvae; Spiders, especially the hunting spiders, prey on adults.
Other predators are ladybird beetles and insectivorous birds (Drongo-Dicrurus adsimilis)
Long-horned grasshopper feeds on egg masses.
Larvae are susceptible to bacterial infections.
Pheromone trapping
Pheromone traps, which are commercially available are very effective in knowing the activity of the adults. They also predict egg laying.
Chemical Control

Sprays are more effective than granules. Spray late in the afternoon. Mix a little brown sugar to increase intake of insecticide by larvae. Mature larvae do not feed voraciously before pupation and tend to go inside the soil for pupation.
